author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Mark Shields, TV Pundit Known for His Sharp Wit, Dies at 85
description: A former campaign strategist, he became a fixture in American political journalism and punditry and was seen on “PBS NewsHour” for 33 years.
content: Mark Shields, a piercing analyst of America’s political virtues and failings, first as a Democratic campaign strategist and then as a television commentator who both delighted and rankled audiences for four decades with his bluntly liberal views and sharply honed wit, died on Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: Despite Growing Evidence, a Prosecution of Trump Would Face Challenges
description: As House hearings highlighted testimony that could create more pressure to pursue a criminal case, the former president tried out a defense that strained credulity.
content: As new questions swirled this past week about former President Donald J. Trump’s potential criminal exposure for seeking to overturn the 2020 election, Mr. Trump issued a rambling 12-page statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Hence, Mike Pence
description: Trump set a fire with lies, then doused Mike Pence in gasoline.
content: WASHINGTON — The fate of a sycophant is never a happy one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: Third Man Arrested in Amazon Slayings of Journalist and Activist
description: The police in Brazil said on Saturday that they had arrested another person connected to the deaths of Dom Phillips and Bruno Araújo Pereira, and said the men been shot to death.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — A third person was arrested on Saturday in connection with the killings of a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples who went missing while deep in the Amazon nearly two weeks ago, the police said before sharing grisly details about how the pair was murdered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: Ukraine’s Death Workers: ‘If You Take It All Close to Heart, You Go Mad’
description: The people toiling in Ukraine’s cemeteries and morgues bear a silent burden as they handle the war’s growing toll.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — For many Ukrainians facing Russia’s invasion, there is hope the daily battles can be won: A soldier may beat back his enemies. A rescuer might miraculously pull a survivor from rubble. A doctor could save a life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Litov
description: Take on Litov in a recreation of a simultaneous exhibition game in Serpukhov, 1915. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: About Daniel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Huge Fire Breaks Out at Sinopec’s Shanghai Complex, Leaving 1 Dead
description: Firefighters were able to put the blaze under control, but it caused residents of a nearby neighborhood to flee their homes.
content: A huge fire broke out Saturday at the headquarters of a petrochemical facility in southeast Shanghai and at least one person died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Bitcoin Plummets Below $20,000 for First Time Since Late 2020
description: Its fall was accelerated in recent weeks by the collapse of two major cryptocurrency projects while sowing doubts about the stability of the overall cryptocurrency market.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The price of Bitcoin fell below $20,000 for the first time since December 2020 on Saturday, amid a broader market meltdown driven by rising interest rates, inflation and economic uncertainty spurred by the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ and ‘The Northman’ Mean for the Movies
description: Two new offerings give a glimpse of what films once were and might become again.
content: Can decline be reversed? Can decadence be resisted? These questions hang over Joe Biden’s America, land of $5 a gallon gas, looming recession, impending electrical-grid failures, 1970s-style urban crisis — not to mention a summer movie slate led by the umpteenth “Jurassic Park” sequel and “Lightyear,” a pathetic Disney cash grab based on fictional pop culture from inside a 1995 Pixar movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Is It Risky to Provide an Apartment to a Home Aide as a Job Benefit?
description: No such arrangement is without risk. Just make sure that the terms of the employer-employee agreement are clearly spelled out.
content: Q: Our family owns and operates a small apartment building in Manhattan. My husband and I live in the ground-floor unit, and the apartment two flights up is vacant. Because my husband has a chronic disease, we are exploring options for home care. Could we provide that vacant apartment, which is market rate, to a home aide as an employment benefit? What would happen if the relationship doesn’t work out and we want to replace the aide with someone else? Would they still have rights to the apartment, or could we directly tie the housing to the job?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: When the World Gives You Lemons … Make a Stand
description: Lemonade stands have adapted for sour times, raising funds and creating fun along the way.
content: When Laura Kurtz staged lemonade stands as a child in Raleigh, N.C., they were simple affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: A Chinese Telescope Did Not Find an Alien Signal. The Search Continues.
description: China’s astronomers have been initiated into the search for extraterrestrial intelligence with the kind of false alarm that others in the field have experienced for decades.
content: It was a project that launched a thousand interstellar dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia: Deaths veiled in secrecy.
description: In Russia, news of death arrives stealthily.
content: In Russia, news of death arrives stealthily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 13, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Ex-Amazon Worker Convicted in Capital One Hacking
description: Paige Thompson’s lawyers said she had been looking for cracks so they could be fixed. A jury found her guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges.
content: A former Amazon engineer who was accused of stealing customers’ personal information from Capital One in one of the largest breaches in the United States was found guilty of wire fraud and hacking charges on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter May
title: At the U.S. Open, Brooks Koepka Is in His Happy Place, and in Contention
description: Koepka, who won the Open in 2017 and 2018, has made no secret of focusing on only the four major tournaments. He could be the perfect candidate to join the LIV Golf series. But will he?
content: BROOKLINE, Mass. — As Brooks Koepka strode down the first fairway on a humid Friday morning, one fan shouted his approval of the golfer’s clothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon
title: Odesa Opera House Reopens, Defying Putin’s Barbarism
description: War is not far away, but a city that has always lived for the moment proclaims that culture will help Ukraine prevail.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — In a nation at war, and a city aching for some semblance of normality, the Odesa Opera reopened for the first time since the Russian invasion began, asserting civilization against the barbarism unleashed from Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Catherine Garcia
title: The Jury in the Bill Cosby Sex Assault Case Says It’s Close to a Verdict
description: The jurors will resume deliberations Monday after saying they had decided most, but not all, of the issues raised in a lawsuit by a woman who says Mr. Cosby molested her in 1975.
content: The jurors in the Bill Cosby sexual assault trial came close to deciding the case on Friday, but their uncertainty over how to address some remaining issues in reaching a verdict led the judge to decide they should return on Monday to resume their deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia May Jonas
title: When a Father Leaves a Prized Possession to a Stranger
description: In Alison Fairbrother’s debut novel, “The Catch,” a grieving daughter is determined to get to the bottom of a baffling inheritance.
content: Writers have forever used objects as a tool by which to tell their stories — Hawthorne’s letter, Maupassant’s necklace, Hammett’s falcon. Follow the bouncing crown, I was taught, as a way to understand the structure of Shakespeare’s history plays. The literary object, at its most effective, is a powerful revealer of character — telling us about the people who possess it and those who covet it; those who are drawn to it and those who are repelled by it; those who deem it meaningless and those who endow it with outsize importance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Rush to E.S.G., With or Without Elon Musk
description: Mr. Musk trashed E.S.G. investing. The S.E.C. is investigating Goldman Sachs’s move into the sector. In a falling market, what should investors consider?
content: Any time the stock market falls, investors are likely to rethink nearly everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Zelensky Visits War-Torn Mykolaiv and Odesa in Southern Ukraine
description: The president’s trip aimed to highlight Ukraine’s grip on the area and to lift the spirits of an embattled populace.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Saturday made unannounced visits to Mykolaiv, a southern Ukrainian city battered by the war that has been held up by Kyiv as a sign of fierce resistance, and the nearby port city of Odesa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: How to Celebrate Juneteenth
description: My wish is that people remember to be reverent during Juneteenth, that they not only celebrate it but also educate themselves about its roots.
content: Juneteenth has been a part of my family tradition for as long as anyone can remember.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: In Constitutional Crises, Democracies Aren’t Always Democratic
description: When political leaders face a constitutional crisis, like that of Jan. 6, the process of collectively deciding how to respond can be messy, arbitrary, and sometimes change the nature of the system itself.
content: If you look for international parallels to the moment last year when Vice President Mike Pence refused to bow to pressure from President Donald J. Trump to help overturn their election defeat, something quickly becomes clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Not Just for the Birds: Avian Influenza Is Also Felling Wild Mammals
description: As a new version of bird flu spread through North America this spring, scientists began finding the virus in red foxes, bobcats and other mammals.
content: Something was wrong with the foxes. That was what callers to the Dane County Humane Society in Wisconsin kept saying in April, as they reported fox kits, or young foxes, behaving in strange ways: shaking, seizing or struggling to stand. The kits, which were often lethargic and wandering by themselves, also seemed unusually easy to approach, showing little fear of humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: French Nuclear Power Crisis Frustrates Europe’s Push to Quit Russian Energy
description: France typically exports electricity, but now it risks blackouts and a need for imported power because of problems at the state nuclear operator.
content: PARIS — Plumes of steam towered above two reactors recently at the Chinon nuclear power plant in the heart of France’s verdant Loire Valley. But the skies above a third reactor there were unusually clear — its operations frozen after the worrisome discovery of cracks in the cooling system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Kremlin Propaganda Softens Up Targets
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 18, 2022.
content: “When you’re hit over the head with the same message, you just drown in it. After awhile, you don’t know what the truth is. The message takes over your reality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: C.D.C. recommends vaccinations of young children.
description: A scientific panel endorsed the shots despite reservations about the paucity of data, and the C.D.C. director quickly endorsed the decision.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Saturday recommended Covid vaccines for children as young as 6 months, who were among the last Americans to qualify for the shots. Parents should be able to start getting young children immunized as soon as Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A Chance Encounter Helps Return Sacred Artifacts to an Indigenous Group
description: The United Nations helped the Yaqui Nation, an Indigenous group in Mexico and the United States, reclaim a deer’s head and other items from a Swedish museum.
content: Nearly 20 years ago, Andrea Carmen, a member of the Yaqui Nation, an Indigenous group in Mexico and the United States, was at an event commemorating International Day of Indigenous Peoples at a museum in Stockholm. Afterward, she was invited to view the museum’s collection of items from the Americas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden Takes Tumble During Bike Ride in Delaware
description: The president did not need medical attention after he fell off his bike at a state park near his vacation home in Rehoboth Beach, according to the White House.
content: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — President Biden fell off his bike on Saturday while trying to dismount in front of a small crowd of reporters and onlookers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Juneteenth Is a Federal Holiday, but in Most States It’s Still Not a Day Off
description: One year after President Biden made Juneteenth a federal holiday, more than 30 states have not authorized the funding that would allow for state employees to take the day off.
content: Last June, President Biden made Juneteenth a federal holiday, proclaiming it as a day for all Americans to commemorate the end of slavery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Solving Crosswords With a Bunch of Friends, Say
description: Brooke Husic soars in her first solo Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Brooke Husic is a familiar name to weekend solvers, but we nearly always see her with a plus-one; this is only her third solo grid and her first solo Saturday (after five collaborations). This was a zippy solve but also a real excursion for me! The trivia was fresh and challenging, and I got lost in misdirects throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Bamberger and Lee Lai
title: For Father’s Day, a Father’s Life
description: A writer remembers his father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nabil Ayers
title: It Took Me 49 Years to Ask the Right Question About My Father
description: Most of us with absent fathers think, “What about me?” We rarely stop to ask, “What about him?”
content: I always know when Mother’s Day is approaching. I love thinking about what new vegetarian restaurant I might take my mother to, or which of the many great photos of her from my childhood I’ll post on Instagram. Father’s Day, on the other hand, has never been on my mental calendar. I usually learn it’s coming when I see an ad for a sturdy piece of luggage or golf gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire, Glenn Thrush and Eric Lipton
title: Gun Sellers’ Message to Americans: Man Up
description: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.
content: Last November, hours after a jury acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of two shooting deaths during antiracism protests in 2020, a Florida gun dealer created an image of him brandishing an assault rifle, with the slogan: “BE A MAN AMONG MEN.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
description: A Los Angeles actor and producer moved across the pond to restore his crumbling ancestral home. But fixing up a 50,000-square-foot manor isn’t easy.
content: People who search genealogy websites often find birth and marriage records, newspaper clippings, faded photographs or maybe a long-lost relative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: N.J. Transit Shuts Down Train Service, Blaming Engineer Sickout
description: The closures came after a day of cancellations across the system that began in the morning and had worsened by the evening.
content: New Jersey Transit abruptly shut down all rail service on Friday evening amid what officials said was a coordinated effort by the system’s engineers’ union to call in sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Vaccines for Young Children Are Coming, but Many Parents Have Tough Questions
description: The vaccines seem safe for children and are likely to protect against severe illness. But data on efficacy are thin, and most children have already been infected.
content: It’s a moment many parents have anxiously awaited for months: Children younger than age 5 are now eligible for vaccination against the coronavirus, among the last Americans to qualify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Lara Jakes
title: Trump’s Shadow Looms Over Fading Iran Nuclear Talks
description: With no compromise in sight and Iran making steady progress toward nuclear capability, the Biden administration could soon face a stark choice.
content: WASHINGTON — Many factors are to blame for the dying prospects of reviving the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. But perhaps nothing has hobbled the Biden administration’s efforts more than the legacy of President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The World Has a Choice: Work Together or Fall Apart
description: No single country can solve the problem of rising food and fuel costs.
content: It is a natural human impulse, and a political one, to turn inward when threatened by a crisis that appears beyond our control. The world is facing several such forces at once: food shortages, inflation, the persistence of Covid-19 and the effects of global warming. Taken together, they threaten the stability and prosperity of nations around the world. That threat could hasten the retreat that many countries are already making away from globalization and international cooperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Giang
title: ‘The Dirty Secret of Covid’: Scott Galloway on the Postpandemic Economic Turmoil
description: Mr. Galloway, an outspoken N.Y.U. professor, speaks with DealBook about the crypto crash and what Silicon Valley will look like on the other side.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: School’s Catholic Title in Peril Over Pride and Black Lives Matter Flags
description: Bishop Robert J. McManus of the Diocese of Worcester, Mass., said flying the flags contradicts “Catholic social and moral teaching.” The school has refused to take them down.
content: The students at a predominantly Black Catholic middle school in Worcester, Mass., had resoundingly expressed their wishes in January 2021: They wanted Black Lives Matter and Pride flags flown over their place of learning to signal inclusivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: After an Outcry, Johnson Defends Britain’s Plan to Electronically Monitor Refugees
description: A new British government program would fit some asylum seekers with GPS trackers, drawing condemnation from refugee rights organizations who say they are being treated like criminals.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Saturday defended his government’s plans to electronically tag asylum seekers who cross the English Channel, days into a new, yearlong pilot program that has drawn widespread condemnation from refugee and human rights groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Mike Ives
title: ‘Late Show’ Production Team Arrested at U.S. Capitol While Filming Television Stunt
description: The production team members had been recording interviews at the Capitol building for a comedy segment on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.” They were charged with unlawful entry.
content: The police at the United States Capitol have arrested members of a production team for the CBS show “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were filming a segment featuring a salty canine puppet voiced by the comedian Robert Smigel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
title: Declaring Curry and Samosas Enemy No. 1 to Whip the Police Into Shape
description: The police chief in an Indian island territory had a theory: If the boss was watching his officers’ weight, they would too.
content: PORT BLAIR, India — For G. Chitra, an officer in India’s overburdened police forces, pretty much everything in her life is bad for her health. Working irregular hours is a source of stress. Standing guard for long periods hurts her knees. Caring for a toddler late at night and rising at 4:30 for household chores leaves her tired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: With Child Care Scarce, States Try to Fix ‘a Broken Market’
description: Federal legislation has stalled, so states are stepping in. In some places, that could mean looser regulations, like 16-year-olds caring for children, without supervision.
content: In New Mexico, child care workers got pay raises. In Iowa, 16-year-olds can now supervise 15 children. In Montana, caregivers can watch more toddlers at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Mike Pence and the Soft Bigotry of Low Expectations
description: How much credit should he get for doing the bare minimum?
content: It is clear that one of the political objectives of the Jan. 6 hearings is to strengthen the anti-insurrection wing of the Republican Party. The vice chair and leading member of the House select committee is Liz Cheney, a Republican. The leading witnesses, like the retired judge J. Michael Luttig and Greg Jacob, are Republicans. And the heroes of the narrative, like the former vice president Mike Pence, are Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Naomi Osaka Withdraws From Wimbledon Citing Achilles’ Injury
description: Osaka has not played at Wimbledon since 2019.
content: Naomi Osaka, the Japanese tennis star who remains a one-surface wonder, will not play at Wimbledon later this month, she announced in a social media post on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Verlyn Klinkenborg
title: Spring Now Comes With a Secret Dread
description: Depending on the arrival of migratory birds for spring to begin means accepting the changing world the birds fly through.
content: EAST CHATHAM, N.Y. — It’s always a relief when the swallows return. One day, they’re suddenly here, flickering around the house eaves, and whatever was waiting on them to begin — like spring — can now begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Your child is almost 5. Here’s what some experts say about Covid vaccine options for that age group.
description: Parents of 4-year-olds should start the vaccination process as soon as possible, according to experts, even if that means beginning with the lower-dose version.
content: Understandably, many parents of young children have questions about the new coronavirus vaccines for babies and toddlers and the expected rollout next week of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna shots. We talked with infectious disease pediatricians to get answers to the most common ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: 2 Dead and 10 Injured in Boat Collision in Florida, Officials Say
description: Twelve people were in the vessels at the time of the crash and “they were all launched out of their boats,” said Jose Hernandez, a Coast Guard spokesman.
content: Two people were killed and 10 others injured on Friday night after two boats collided near Key Biscayne, Fla., an island town a few miles southeast of Miami, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Uterine Cancer Is on the Rise, Especially Among Black Women
description: The cancer eventually will become the third most common type among women, experts say. The mortality rate is highest among Black Americans.
content: Linda Collins had been in menopause for almost a decade when she started bleeding again. The bleeding was light — occasional spotting, really — and she barely gave it a passing thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stella Bugbee and Indya Brown
title: The Existential Crossroads of Bathing Suit Shopping
description: Trying to make a cursed endeavor less fraught? Us, too.
content: It’s finally, truly, hotly swim season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer Begins
description: The season is almost here, finally, with all its sun-dappled splendor and glorious clichés.
content: Summer starts in the Northern Hemisphere at 5:14 a.m. Eastern on Tuesday. It’s the longest day of 2022, as good a reason as any to linger outdoors, to welcome the season that the poet Amy Lowell called “The very crown of nature’s changing year / When all her surging life is at its full.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Fawcett, Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Christina Capecchi, Ellen B. Meacham, Kevin Williams and Adam Bednar
title: A vaccine for young children? U.S. parents’ reactions remain mixed.
description: Many parents have greeted the news that young children can soon be vaccinated against Covid with a sigh of relief. Others have deep reservations.
content: For many parents across the United States, the long-awaited news that young children would soon become eligible for a coronavirus vaccine was met with a rush of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! It’s Been More Than 2 Years and I Still Don’t Have the Refund
description: Our columnist has received many reader emails complaining of tour operators and travel agencies dragging their feet on refunds for trips or other services. He investigates a $334 fare with Euro Railways.
content: When the pandemic broke out in March 2020, my wife and I cut short a trip to Norway, changing flights and canceling reservations that included a train ride from Bergen to Oslo that we had booked using Euro Railways. All the other vendors reimbursed us long ago, but we still haven’t received the $334 we’re owed from Euro Railways. In August 2020, the company’s director, Tom Louis, wrote to “ask our creditors for time to reorganize our finances” to avoid declaring bankruptcy. Fair enough. But since then, they have not responded to our emails. Any help would be very much appreciated. Douglas in Richfield, Minn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Some Light Reading
description: Jeremy Newton’s puzzle makes us look both ways.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jeremy Newton is a software engineer in Austin, Texas, who works on mobile games. This is his 15th Sunday grid and 22nd puzzle since 2007, and it was inspired by a stop at an intersection last fall. It took several months to work out all of the elements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The battlefield: A kaleidoscope of death.
description: Some of the most lethal weapons ever used have been unleashed on both sides in appalling quantities: cluster rockets, self-detonating mines, battle tanks, howitzers, thermobarics and incendiary munition.
content: Outgoing, incoming, the whistle, the screech and the bang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: Several Killed in Militant Attack on a Sikh Temple in Afghanistan
description: The assault in the capital, Kabul, was the latest in a series targeting the country’s religious minorities that have stoked fears about the Taliban’s ability to provide security.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Militants stormed a Sikh temple in Afghanistan’s capital on Saturday, leaving several people dead and others wounded, and stoking already heightened concerns among the country’s religious minorities about whether the new Taliban government will be able to protect them from rising violence by extremist groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Nicholas Fandos
title: How Many N.Y. Democrats Does It Take to Fill a House Seat? Try 15.
description: A congressman, an ex-congresswoman, an ex-mayor, a Trump prosecutor and several state and city officials are eyeing an open congressional seat in New York City.
content: Beneath a maple tree by a red brick elementary school in Brooklyn, a lanky, recognizable figure lingered on a recent morning, hoping to catch the attention of moms, dads, the grounds worker mowing the lawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruthie Ackerman
title: I.V.F. Gave Me My Daughter. What Will Happen After Roe?
description: Extreme anti-abortion laws could hinder assisted reproductive technologies, too.
content: After I struggled to get pregnant for many years, my partner, Rob, and I finally had our daughter in August 2020, thanks to some alchemy of science and serendipity. We had gone into our in vitro fertilization experience wanting one child. But in those exhausting days after she was born — and in the many months since — the five leftover embryos from our I.V.F. cycle, frozen in liquid nitrogen, have called out to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carly Olson and Johnny Diaz
title: Here’s how the doses of the two vaccines for young children differ.
description: Vaccines from Pfizer and its partner BioNTech are already been available for Americans 6 and older, and Moderna’s vaccines have been approved for adults.
content: Federal health officials on Saturday cleared the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccines for very young children —  the only age group in the United States that does not yet have a vaccine option available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Hurdle and Ava Sasani
title: Philadelphia Firefighter Dies in Building Collapse
description: A 27-year veteran of the Fire Department was pronounced dead at the scene, fire officials said. Five others were injured.
content: PHILADELPHIA — A pizzeria collapsed in Philadelphia early on Saturday morning, killing one firefighter and injuring four other firefighters and a city building official, the Philadelphia Fire Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
description: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
content: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Centers For Disease Control And Prevention Via Youtube
title: C.D.C. Recommends Covid-19 Vaccines for Children Under 5
description: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, endorsed the decision after a scientific panel backed the shots despite reservations about a paucity of data.
content: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, endorsed the decision after a scientific panel backed the shots despite reservations about a paucity of data.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is It Ethical to Have Children Amid the Climate Crisis?

title: Corrections: June 18, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 18, 2022.
content: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a TikTok account dedicated to New York’s publicly accessible bathrooms misidentifies the profession of an author of a study on public bathrooms in New York City. Boyeong Hong is a data analyst, not an urban planner.
source.name: The New York Times
